>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-06-18 --------------------
>On Tue, 2003-06-1=
7 at 18:55, J. B. Rainsberger wrote: 
>> I disagree. Model objects represen=
ting values should be transparent, a
>la "Naked Objects". They should let t=
he Model objects containing business
>logic "do with them what they may". T=
here is a tendency in OOP to pretend
>there is behavior where there is no b=
ehavior. I think that is a mistake.
>Some objects in the system are just ba=
gs of data. I think public fields
>should do nicely there. Ward Cunningham =
has been experimenting with
>ignoring the prevaling paranoia against public=
 data. I haven't seen him
>write anything on it yet, but it's good to test =
long-standing "rules".
>
>I agree with that when it is applied to "data str=
uctures," the naked
>objects you refer to, but not behavioral objects.  I d=
on't think you
>were applying it to the latter, I just wanted to be clear.
=

Exactly. I'm with you. Sometimes, it's just a bag of data. Maps would do.
=

>> One counterexample is an object with 20 fields. Perhaps 20 set methods
=
>is clearer, at least in a language like Java with positional parameters.
>=
(In Smalltalk it's exactly the same, so it doesn't matter.) Should an
>obje=
ct have 20 fields? Perhaps not, but some do. It is not clear that
>breaking=
 that 20-field objects into four 5-field objects is any better.
>
>A twist =
on that... If that object needs to have 20 fields (which I don't
>believe i=
t does) you can group fields together into other objects such
>that this ob=
ject is a wrapper on 5 others, each with 4 fields.  The data
>is still in o=
ne place, but it's creation is much less cumbersome and you
>can create it =
in a sane state.

I don't know that this is better: now I have to build fiv=
e or six objects, and not just one. I think the creation is *no less* cumbe=
rsome in this case. That has been my observation.

Take care.
